The garden of the Saint Louis hospital is truly inspiring, while browsing the site I was able to discover this garden. We find ourselves in a mythical place steeped in history. We are captivated by the trees there and the colorful nest boxes perched on some of them in this place full of serenity and well-being. We discover in particular a gigantic tree, a Paulonia Tomentosa, more than 150 years old, imposing with its presence 3.36m in circumference to tell you that we cannot pass by without seeing it, especially since it is marked by the weight of the years with its shapes. which command admiration, it is so magnificent. I invite myself to greet him during each of my visits and explore this peaceful place. You just feel like you're transported to another time. üôèüå≥
Magnificent garden with its trees and small stone benches. All round borders old and beautiful buildings A very calm haven where we ate our very good sandwich in the hospital cafeteria.
very pretty with vouchers everywhere, you don't hear the Paris traffic you'd think you were somewhere else. And some trees have a plaque with a story. Very nice!!!
Extraordinary discovery of a tree 150 years old, of origin from Asia and China. It was by coincidence a visit to the garden of the Saint-Louis hospital in Paris

Very beautiful garden between venerable Louis XIII period walls, planted with interesting trees. In all seasons, walking there is a privilege...resting there, making a phone call, taking your lunch/coffee break, meeting up with colleagues, taking the sun or taking the time... it's also a pleasure, a joy, a diversion before after an exam, a consultation... before diving back into the city, the noise, the traffic... .

Yesterday I visited a friend who had major surgery. She wanted to get some quiet air. Big miss! Between the picnics of 10 people, the children playing with balloons and shouting. People hospitalized should be able to stay there after 6 p.m., closing time for Parisians, they would really benefit from the calm. It is above all a hospital!

A charming haven of peace a stone's throw from the Saint Martin canal, always crowded when the weather is nice. The fault of this garden? It closes way too early!

Hello, it's a place like nowhere else obviously... This typical square garden is that of the old St Louis hospital, obviously that commands respect. Full of history, memories, a park divided into four parts with a small central roundabout. It goes wonderfully with the buildings that surround it, vestiges of old St Louis where there are still medical services. absolutely discover
A haven of greenery and tranquility in this hospitable hive that is so useful but so stressful. Good for small children who cannot see their hospitalized parent, relaxation for caregivers.
Little neighborhood treasure to read a book or take a nap.
I like this little garden at the Saint Louis hospital. I go there quite often as a regular patient at this hospital and it's nice to be able to relax for a few minutes and be peaceful in this garden.
A quiet, wooded place within the grounds of this historic and modern hospital). Always in bloom.

For dermatological emergencies, you have to be there at 5 a.m. to be sure of being taken. For those who live nearby it's okay, but for those who come from outside Paris it's too complicated. Not appreciated

Very nice, pleasant, quiet, it's good to be able to relax there... Especially when the weather is nice.

Even if this garden is located in a Hospital, you should not hesitate to visit it  History : Following serious plague epidemics which ravaged Paris in 1605 and 1606, Henry IV decided to build a hospital outside Paris to accommodate contagious patients and at the same time keep them away from the capital. This will be named ‚ÄúSaint-Louis‚Äù in honor of the king who was then thought to have died of the plague (he would in fact have died of dysentery).  The first stone was laid in July 1607. To avoid any contact with the outside population, the hospital and its square courtyard were surrounded by gardens and walls. It is this old central courtyard which is today a pleasant public garden which can be enjoyed freely.  The ground floors were used as cellars and stores while the sick were housed on the upper floors. Behind this central square, the square buildings that you can see as you walk around the outside of the garden served as staff accommodation. Galleries connected these brackets to the central building to avoid ‚Äì once again ‚Äì any contact with the outside.  Finally, observe the architecture and style of the four large buildings that surround the garden. The slate roofs and the facades where red brick and cut stone mix are reminiscent of another major work of Henry IV: the Place des Vosges. Indeed, the architect of the Saint-Louis hospital, Claude Vellefaux, had also worked on the design of the Place Royale!  The Saint-Louis chapel, opened to the public on August 25, 1609, was intended for the population of the suburbs around the hospital.  Today it is a family garden where residents of the neighborhood meet. Still unknown to the general public, it offers a pleasant stopover in history and greenery in the heart of the 10th arrondissement.
Little secret place. You have to enter the hospital and follow the directions. Once in the garden you will forget that you are in Paris. Calm and serenity await you.
Peaceful place within the hospital which allows you to leave the room and receive the patient's family. Very pleasant shaded site.
A relaxing place which on this very hot day brought me a moment of rest
It is not a public garden, this garden is reserved for patients and their visitors, nursing staff and their children. No pets allowed. You are without a hospital!
Very pleasant place, allows you to spend time under super beautiful trees
A garden of significant size but completely isolated from the street, therefore calm in the middle of the old hospital buildings. Surprising.
A place conducive to calm and relaxation, especially when the sun appears. Magnificent historical monument.
